title: Exposing the Risk, yet Moving Forward: a Behavioral E-Health Model
affiliation: 1 Director of Telehealth and E-Health for Alliant University. She has served as the California Psychological Association's Presidential Telehealth Task Force Chairperson, and on the American Psychological Association's Committee on Professional Practice Standards (COPPS). President of Pioneer Development Resources, Inc., she is a frequent speaker and Internet consultant. Founder and Editor-in-Chief of SelfhelpMagazine.com, she directs one of the first and largest online mental health websites. She also developed a professional website for research and networking called Telehealth.net. She is lead author of E-Health, Telehealth, and Telemedicine: A Guide to Start-up and Success, published in 2001 by Jossey-Bass. Her next book is tentatively entitled The Mental Health Practitioner Online: New Questions & Answers for Practice Today, with Lawrence Erlbaum Associates.

title: The Evolution of the Digital Divide: How Gaps in Internet Access May Impact Electronic Commerce
affiliation: 3 Assistant Professor of Marketing at Vanderbilt University. Before coming to Vanderbilt, Dr. Schlosser was a postdoctoral research associate in interactive marketing at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA). In 1997, she received the @d:tech Scholarship for individual contribution to understanding the influence of technology on advertising, communication, and marketing. Her research has appeared in the Journal of Consumer Psychology, Journal of Interactive Marketing, Computer Supported Cooperative Work, Handbook on Electronic Commerce and Advertising and The World Wide Web. Dr. Schlosser specializes in consumer behavior in virtual environments. Her current research projects include studying consumer interaction in computer-mediated environments, Web site design and its impact on attitude strength and brand loyalty, and consumer control in computer environments.

title: Mediated Perceptions: Contributions of Phenomenological Film Theory to Understanding the Interactive Video Experience
affiliation: 2 Director of the Human Computer Interaction Group (HCI Group) and an Associate Professor of Communication at Cornell University. The HCI Group is a research and development group whose members design and research the use of computer-mediated learning environments. Professor Gay's research interests focus on cognitive and social issues for the design and use of interactive communication technologies. Professor Gay has received funding for her research and design projects from the National Science Foundation, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Mellon Foundation, Intel, Microsoft, IBM, Getty, and several private donors. She teaches courses in interactive multimedia design and research, computer-mediated communication, human-computer interaction, and the social design of communication systems.

title: Community Development among Distance Learners: Temporal and Technological Dimensions
affiliation: 1 Assistant Professor at the Graduate School of Library and Information Science, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. affiliation: 1 Geoffrey Z. Liu, after several years of teaching in the Department of Library and Information Science, Central-China Normal University, was invited to come to University of Hawaii at Manoa as a visiting fellow in 1989 and later entered the Interdisciplinary Doctoral Program in Communication and Information Sciences. He earned his Ph.D. in 1994 with a dissertation on information retrieval using natural language processing techniques. In the fall of 1995, he joined the faculty at the School of Library and Information Science, San Jose State University, as an assistant professor. His research interests include natural language processing, automatic indexing, information retrieval, and social impacts of information technologies.

affiliation: 2 Associate Professor in the School of Cognitive and Computing Sciences at Sussex University in the UK, where she teaches Human Computer Interaction and Cognitive Science. title: The Crossroads between Lifelong Learning and Information Technology a Challenge Facing Leading Universities
affiliation: 2 B.Sc. in Industrial and Management Engineering from the Technion in Haifa, and a Master in Business Administration (MBA) from Tel Aviv University. In particular, he was involved in setting up and directing “Ofek”– an interactive distance learning system via satellite. affiliation: 2 Associate Professor of information systems at INSEAD. She received her PhD in Information Systems from the University of Texas at Austin, from where she also received her MBA and BA. Dr. Leidner has published her research in such journals as MIS Quarterly, Information Systems Research, Organization Science, Decision Support Systems, and the Journal of Management Information Systems. title: Bridging the Gulfs: from Hypertext to Cyberspace
affiliation: 1 Assistant Professor at the Department of Communication, Université de Montréal, where he co-directs the Research Laboratory in Multimedia Communication. He joined the department in 1993 after two years as a visiting scholar at the Annenberg School for Communication, University of Southern California. His research program, entitled “The Social Construction of the New Media User”, is devoted to the social history of the new communication technologies, with an emphasis on the history of personal computing and the sociology of artistic development and uses of the new media. Author of approximately a dozen papers or book chapters in Science, Technology and Human Values, Knowledge and Policy, Technologies de l'Information et Société, Réseaux, and other journals, Bardini is currently working on the manuscript of his first book, The Personal Interface, forthcoming in 1998 from Stanford University Press.

title: “Hmmm…Where'S That Smoke Coming from?”
affiliation: 1 Brenda Danet is Professor of Sociology and Communication at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. She has been studying aspects of language, communication, and culture on the Internet since 1991. Her interests include the nature and implications of playfulness in digital communication; consequences of the loss of the text as material object in computerized communication; the new media and the future of performativity; email and the history of letter-writing; gender, play and performance on the Internet; and virtual theatre. During the 1996-97 academic year she is on sabbatical at the Center for Folklife Programs & Cultural Studies, The Smithsonian Institution, Washington, DC, where she is working on a book Keybo@rd K@perz: Play, Culture and Communication in the Early Digital Age. Research for this paper was initiated while he was a visiting research professor at the University of California, Irvine. His Ph.D. degree in economics is from the University of Arkansas. As a National Science Foundation Faculty-Science Fellow, he did postdoctoral study and research at the Graduate School of Industrial Administration, Carnegie Institute of Technology, in the quantitative and behavioral sciences. The author's recent research has been in organizational and individual learning. He has been on the faculties of the University of Arkansas and the University of Texas. He is on the editorial advisory staff of the Southwestern Social Science Quarterly. His latest book is Compound Statements and Mathematical Logic published by Charles Merrill in 1967. He is also co-editor of Merrill's Mathematics and Quantitative Methods Series
